trial_identification.studytitle: School-based prevention of symptoms of depression and anxiety (negative affect) in adolescents.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: For adolescent high school students, will the Healthy Minds prevention and wellbeing program, when compared to lessons-as-usual controls, prevent the onset of negative affect.

conditions.healthcondition: Symptoms of depression and anxiety (negative affect)

interventions.interventions:
Lessons provided in class time that teach psychological skills.
These consisted of one lesson (50 minutes) per week over 8 consecutive weeks. Skills and concepts taught include: - costs of unhelpful perfectionism - realistic & balanced thinking (cognitive skills) - emotion regulation strategies - media literacy - self-compassion - gratitude
Lessons were administered by a psychologist but teachers were present at all lessons.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Mean scores on the Depression, Anxiety, Stress Scale (DASS)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Follow-up time points are post-intervention, 6-month follow-up & 12-month follow-up.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Scores on the Frost Multidimentional Perfectionism Scale

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
Enrolled at participating schools in the designated year level.
Age range was Year 8 to Year 10 (approximately 13 year olds to 15 year olds)

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The study was a universal prevention program targeting the onset of symptoms of depression and anxiety in adolescent school students. It target unhelpful perfectionism as a risk factor, was conducted across 4 sites, with more 750 Year 8-10 students participating.
Our hypothesis was that the intervention group would exhibit a lower rate of onset of symptoms of depression and anxiety. A prevention effect over the 6-month follow-up period was confirmed.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Flinders Social and Behavioural Research Ethics Committee
ethicscommitee.ethicaddress: GPO box 2100 Adelaide SA 5001 Approval granted 21/10/10 Project approval number 5020
